question_text: How does the Solar Aided Power Generation (SAPG) approach achieve thermodynamic leverage in a regenerative Rankine cycle, and what are the key factors limiting its maximum solar share according to the provided paper?
standard_answer: SAPG achieves thermodynamic leverage by using solar heat to preheat feedwater in a regenerative Rankine cycle, displacing steam extraction from turbines. In a regenerative cycle, steam is bled at various stages to heat feedwater, reducing work output but improving efficiency. By injecting solar heat at feedwater heater temperatures (90–350°C), the bled steam is redirected to expand further in the turbine, generating additional work. The solar heat effectively converts low-temperature input into high-temperature equivalent work, as the displaced steam would have been extracted at higher temperatures. This results in solar-to-power efficiencies that can approach 45.3% at 260°C input for super-critical cycles, which represents a significant efficiency boost compared to stand-alone solar systems at the same temperature. Key factors limiting maximum solar share include: (1) turbine turn-down capabilities, which restrict how much steam flow can be adjusted; (2) practical constraints in retrofitting existing plants, such as land availability for solar collectors and heliostat field sizing; (3) the finite number of feedwater heaters and their temperature ranges; and (4) solar resource variability, which reduces the annually averaged solar share despite high instantaneous shares. The instantaneous solar share is only about 5% when solar thermal input is provided at 90°C, while it approaches about 25% at 260°C in the super-critical case.
